entry.title: Volagi Viaje 2025 Update
entry.summary: The creme-colored Volagi Viaje SL steel bike saw several updates in 2023 and 2024. The first round of changes was in October 2023, when I switched it from a 2x12 to a 1x12 drivetrain. In March 2024, I swapped derailleurs, and in October, I replaced the Hope calipers. I have a new project in mind for 2025 for which I needed some of the Volagi's components. In doing so, I decided to disassemble my Ritte Snob Disc. I moved the carbon Rotor Aldhu cranks, the spider, the SRAM Red derailleur, the saddle, and the seat post from the Ritte to the Volagi. I also bought a new 4-bolt, 44T Rotor QRing, and a WolfTooth LoneWolf chain guide.
entry.content:
The creme-colored Volagi Viaje SL steel bike saw several updates in 2023 and 2024. The first round of changes was in October 2023, when I switched it from a 2x12 to a 1x12 drivetrain. In March 2024, I swapped derailleurs, and in October, I replaced the Hope calipers. I have a new project in mind for 2025 for which I needed some of the Volagi's components. In doing so, I decided to disassemble my Ritte Snob Disc. I moved the carbon Rotor Aldhu cranks, the spider, the SRAM Red derailleur, the saddle, and the seat post from the Ritte to the Volagi. I also bought a new 4-bolt, 44T Rotor QRing, and a WolfTooth LoneWolf chain guide.

The 4-bolt, 44-tooth, oval Rotor chainring is a work of art. Its CNC-machining is pure perfection. Designed as a dedicated 1x ring, the chain line is moved inward by millimeters. There's ample chainstay clearance, so I love that, as it minimizes the cross-chain effect when riding in the larger cogs, which I use far more than the smallest two cogs.

I replaced the newer Zipp seat post with the older generation post purely for aesthetics. The fork, Thomson handlebar, and Rotor cranks all have a high-gloss finish, and the older, glossy post better matched this. All I have to do now is ride it.

At first, I thought about selling the Ritte Snob Disc frameset and the Industry Nine wheelset, but I'm not ready to part with this bike yet. Instead, I decided to pack it into my travel case. Recently, I saw spy shots of the new SRAM Force road groupset published online. Like the new Red groupset, Force remains a 2x12 configuration. The new Force components would look great on the Ritte, so why not reassemble it in a year or two with those parts?

entry.title: ZTTO 12-Speed 10-44T XDR Cassette
entry.summary: Cassette options have been limited if you’re running a 1x12 XPLR drivetrain on a road or gravel bike. In XDR, SRAM offers the XG-1251 all-steel cassette as well as the XG-1271 with the largest cog in aluminum. There’s also the PG-1231 11-44T for Shimano driver bodies. They never made a Red-level 12-speed cassette to match their Red XPLR derailleur. There’s Garbaruk’s meticulously machined cassette. Eleven of the cogs are CNC-machined out of a solid block of steel. A 44T aluminum sprocket is bolted to that. At 280 grams, it’s the most lightweight gravel cassette. Priced at 280 euros, it costs a euro per gram. It’s a beautiful cassette, and I will certainly get one.
entry.content:
Cassette options have been limited if you’re running a 1x12 XPLR drivetrain on a road or gravel bike. In XDR, SRAM offers the XG-1251 all-steel cassette as well as the XG-1271 with the largest cog in aluminum. There’s also the PG-1231 11-44T for Shimano driver bodies. They never made a Red-level 12-speed cassette to match their Red XPLR derailleur. There’s Garbaruk’s meticulously machined cassette. Eleven of the cogs are CNC-machined out of a solid block of steel. A 44T aluminum sprocket is bolted to that. At 280 grams, it’s the most lightweight gravel cassette. Priced at 280 euros, it costs a euro per gram. It’s a beautiful cassette, and I will certainly get one.

ZTTO now offers a lightweight, affordable alternative. The cassette’s construction is very similar to that from Garbaruk. 11 cogs (10-38T) are machined out of a solid block of high-strength steel. The 44T cog is made from 7075 aluminum and riveted to the two largest steel cogs. Here’s how the different cassettes compare:

Brand Cassette Freehub Gearing Weight Difference (*) Price Difference (*) Cost/gram
SRAM PG-1231 Shimano Road 11-12-13-15-17-19-21-24-28-32-38-44 425 g + 0 g 117.50 EUR - 10.00 EUR 0.28 EUR/g
SRAM XG-1251 (*) SRAM XDR 10-11-13-15-17-19-21-24-28-32-38-44 425 g + 0 g 127.50 EUR + 0.00 EUR 0.30 EUR/g
SRAM XG-1271 SRAM XDR 10-11-13-15-17-19-21-24-28-32-38-44 378 g - 47 g 177.50 EUR + 50.00 EUR 0.47 EUR/g
ZTTO 10-44T SRAM XDR 10-11-13-15-17-19-21-24-28-32-38-44 342 g - 83 g 99.00 EUR - 28.50 EUR 0.29 EUR/g
Garbaruk 10-44T SRAM XD 10-11-12-14-16-18-21-24-28-32-37-44 280 g - 145 g 280.00 EUR + 152.50 EUR 1.00 EUR/g

ZTTO and SRAM use identical cog sizes. Garbaruk decided to have 1-tooth jumps for the first three gears, and 2-tooth jumps for the next three. Gear 6 through 12 are the same for both cassettes, except for the 11th cog. SRAM has a 38-teeth cog, while Garbaruk went one smaller with 37 teeth. I dislike the jump from 11 to 13 teeth on the SRAM cassette. The chain sitting on the 11T cog often feels too hard of a gear. Shifting up one gear then feels too much of a change. I’m missing that 12T in between. The gear changes on the Garbaruk cassette are possibly smoother. I use the 44T only on steep climbs when I’m too tired to ride out of the saddle. I mostly climb in the 28T and 32T and only use the 38T when it gets steep. Riding in the same fashion should be doable with a 37T.

My ZTTO cassette arrived well-packaged in a small cardboard box. No original packaging or instructions were included, but I don’t mind that, as packaging just creates unnecessary trash. The cassette has a claimed weight of 342 grams, but mine actually weighs only 325 grams. That's only 45 grams more than the Garbaruk cassette at a third of the price. The machining quality and overall finish of the cassette are outstanding. The saying used to be: "Weight, price, strength. Pick two". This no longer seems to apply to products like the ZTTO cassette. You get all three: light, good, and inexpensive.

entry.title: Living Up To The Site's Name
entry.summary: The past two weekends I lived up to the name of this blog. I fat-biked off-trail. On Sunday, January 12th I took my fat-bike to Les Prés d'Orvin for a loop to the Petit Chasseral. The snow conditions were spectacular. The weather however wasn't. It was foggy and a cold wind was blowing. I don't mind that. When I'm out fat-biking on snow, the snow quality is all that matters. The days ahead of the 12th were warm with rainfall. On Friday, the mercury started dropping and went well below zero on the weekend. That gave the snow a nice, hard crust thick enough to carry a cyclist and his fat-bike. This is the absolute best snow a fat-biker can wish for. There’s no need to follow trails of any kind. That's what I love, and that's what I did. The only thing that strong winds and fog don't offer is opportunities to shoot good photos.
entry.content:
The past two weekends I lived up to the name of this blog. I fat-biked off-trail. On Sunday, January 12th I took my fat-bike to Les Prés d'Orvin for a loop to the Petit Chasseral. The snow conditions were spectacular. The weather however wasn't. It was foggy and a cold wind was blowing. I don't mind that. When I'm out fat-biking on snow, the snow quality is all that matters. The days ahead of the 12th were warm with rainfall. On Friday, the mercury started dropping and went well below zero on the weekend. That gave the snow a nice, hard crust thick enough to carry a cyclist and his fat-bike. This is the absolute best snow a fat-biker can wish for. There’s no need to follow trails of any kind. That's what I love, and that's what I did. The only thing that strong winds and fog don't offer is opportunities to shoot good photos.

The weekend of January 18th and 19th had it all: good snow and a blue sky. I rode for over three hours and 26 km on Saturday, and nearly 4 hours and 28 km on Sunday. Most of the kilometers I rode were off-trail. The wind and weather were perfect for using my DJI Neo. I took it out of my backpack frequently and let it follow me. The video footage isn't something I'd post on YouTube or elsewhere. It's not like I have the skills of a Danny MacAskill or a Brandon Semenuk, and who really wants to watch an old guy ride his fat-bike across the snow? The videos captured dozens of great photos, which I quickly extracted before dinner at home. I uploaded over sixty pictures from those two rides to Flickr.

Until last weekend, I used the DJI Fly app on my iPhone to control the Neo. When the Neo follows me, it’s nice to glance down at the phone to check what the Neo is doing. There’s one major disadvantage, though. Keeping the DJI Fly app running for an extended period drains the battery. So this weekend, I left my iPhone in the pocket of my jacket and used the quick-mode buttons on the Neo. I listened to the sounds and watched for the shadow to ensure it followed. Twice, the Neo couldn’t keep up. When that happens, the drone stops and hovers in place. I turned around and rode toward the Neo. As soon as it recognized me, it flew straight toward me and jumped back into follow mode. In a year or two, I’m definitely getting a faster drone. I’m sure DJI and HOVERAir will compete to produce even more capable self-flying drones. Until then, the Neo is more than good enough.

entry.title: 2024 Is A Wrap
entry.summary: Although I’m far from where I was in 2017/18, I logged more rides in 2024 than in the past two years. All the numbers, time spent in the saddle, overall distance, and total elevation climbed are up. I spent 75.6% of my riding time on the road, 17.2% on the fat bike, and only 7.2% mountain biking. Ideally, I’d like to share an equal amount of time for each activity type. Yesterday, I uploaded my 10,000th photo to Flickr, most of which are cycling-related. What’s next?
entry.content:
Although I’m far from where I was in 2017/18, I logged more rides in 2024 than in the past two years. All the numbers, time spent in the saddle, overall distance, and total elevation climbed are up. I spent 75.6% of my riding time on the road, 17.2% on the fat bike, and only 7.2% mountain biking. Ideally, I’d like to share an equal amount of time for each activity type. Yesterday, I uploaded my 10,000th photo to Flickr, most of which are cycling-related. What’s next?

  • logging an all-time distance of 80,150 km on Strava
  • logging 5,000 all-time hours
  • logging 2,500,000 m all-time elevation gain, and after that, 300 Everests
  • reaching my 2,000th activity

Not all of the above has to be achieved next year, just whenever is fine with me. The end of the year allowed me to fat bike a lot right from home with no money spent on gas and parking. If I don’t have to pollute our planet and waste time traveling, I prefer that. Weekends are short enough already. What I don’t spend behind the wheel, I can spend behind a handlebar. Last week, that was over 15 hours behind the Jones bar of my Snakedriver.

No new bike joined my stable in 2024, but all bikes saw updates except for my Stooge MK5. I blogged about the changes to my bikes throughout the year. I replaced the 150 mm Thomson Covert dropper post on my 44 Snakedriver in early November with a 185 mm BikeYoke Revive 3.0 dropper post. I also treated the bike to a Chris King seatpost clamp matching the gold King headset and bottom bracket.

I spent 2024 on three bikes: the Marin Gestalt X12, the Stooge MK5, and the 44 Snakedriver. I’m considering selling my Ritte frameset and its wheels in spring 2025. I’d move the Red AXS brake/shift levers and the carbon Rotor Aldhu cranks from it to my Volagi Viaje. The leftover parts will be transferred to a new bike I’d like to assemble sometime during 2025. The Ritte is a jaw-droppingly gorgeous road bike. It’s just that I’ve moved on, and traditional road bikes with skinny tires are no longer my thing. Nothing’s set in stone yet, though.

Lastly, I bought a DJI Neo in September, which I use for the photos posted here. I use the Neo's videos to extract snapshots from the recordings. I marvel at how well that little drone can follow me each time I watch the videos. It's intelligent enough to recognize branches and other obstacles that get in the way. I help the drone, though, by picking my lines based on the safest path for the drone. When there are a lot of branches hanging across the trail, I also slow down so that the Neo has more time to figure out the best flight path. I uploaded a recent video to Flickr if you're curious how the Neo can follow a cyclist through the woods. It was the best purchase of the year, period.

entry.title: Three Months Of Riding With The DJI Neo
entry.summary: If you haven’t read my previous posts about the DJI Neo, check out my introduction and why I think it is the ideal drone for cyclists. I’ve owned the Neo for three months and brought it along on several road rides and, more recently, fat-bike rides in the snow. I use an EVOC Hydro Pro 3L bike vest and a small SunnyLife protective case to carry the DJI Neo while riding. The case only fits the Neo, measures 175x156x76 mm, and weighs 205 grams. Sunnylife now also makes a butterfly body bag for the Neo, weighing only 73 grams. The best places to get them are AliExpress or Temu.
entry.content:
If you haven’t read my previous posts about the DJI Neo, check out my introduction and why I think it is the ideal drone for cyclists. I’ve owned the Neo for three months and brought it along on several road rides and, more recently, fat-bike rides in the snow. I use an EVOC Hydro Pro 3L bike vest and a small SunnyLife protective case to carry the DJI Neo while riding. The case only fits the Neo, measures 175x156x76 mm, and weighs 205 grams. Sunnylife now also makes a butterfly body bag for the Neo, weighing only 73 grams. The best places to get them are AliExpress or Temu.

While I strongly discourage using the Neo on roads where you might encounter other traffic, I have found that it’ll have no issues with a car if it follows you far and high. Just move to the side of the road; the Neo will do the same. In early November, DJI released firmware update V01.00.0400 that increased the speed in tracking mode from 20 km/h to over 32 km/h. On flat farm roads, where I’ve used it, the Neo can more easily keep up with me if there’s no headwind.

Lots of snow blanketed Switzerland the week of November 20th. This was the first opportunity to test the Neo in the snow. I brought it with me on multiple occasions, and it performed flawlessly. On a recent fat-bike ride in Les Prés d’Orvin, a young couple asked me about it when they noticed the Neo behind me. The young woman had seen a travel influencer on TikTok using one. After watching the Neo land in my palm and hearing how easy it is to operate and how inexpensive it is, the young woman told her boyfriend she would get one. It truly is a cool little tool.

entry.title: The P-Brakes That Came Years Before V-Brakes
entry.summary: The first bike components I designed and manufactured were a set of linear-pull cantilever MTB brakes. I designed them in the last year of my apprenticeship and CNC-machined them during summer break in my first year of college. The apprentice department where I did my apprenticeship let me use their machines. I made four tensioner nuts, washers, spring covers, brass sleeves, and steel bushings on a conventional Schäublin 102 tabletop lathe. The lever arms and a fixture to make them were machined on a CNC vertical mill - a Mikron WF31C with a Heidenhain TNC155 control. I worked on those and the larger WF51C during my apprenticeship. I loved working on those and was good at programming them.
entry.content:
The first bike components I designed and manufactured were a set of linear-pull cantilever MTB brakes. I designed them in the last year of my apprenticeship and CNC-machined them during summer break in my first year of college. The apprentice department where I did my apprenticeship let me use their machines. I made four tensioner nuts, washers, spring covers, brass sleeves, and steel bushings on a conventional Schäublin 102 tabletop lathe. The lever arms and a fixture to make them were machined on a CNC vertical mill - a Mikron WF31C with a Heidenhain TNC155 control. I worked on those and the larger WF51C during my apprenticeship. I loved working on those and was good at programming them.

Mechanical Explanation of the P-Brakes

The internal tension spring design was similar to Dia Compe's 986 cantilever brakes. Each arm had an adjustable internal tension spring. One end of the spring fit into a hole in the arm, the other end into an aluminum hex nut used to adjust the spring tension. An aluminum sleeve covered the spring assembly, leaving just the hex bottom visible. A brass sleeve was pressed into the brake arm and the spring cover. 180º opposite from the hole for the spring was a second through-hole. It housed a spring dowel pin that held everything together. This 3-piece assembly revolved around a steel bushing. This bushing had a second function. When tightening the M6 button head mounting bolt, the steel bushing clamped the hex nut to maintain the spring tension. I made a large aluminum washer placed in front of the arm. This was purely aesthetic.

The pad-holding assembly came from Shimano cantilever brakes from that time. It wasn't the easiest to adjust. It was an assembly that was readily available and easy to incorporate. It included an eyebolt-type pad holder, a wedge-shaped washer, and behind the arm, a convex and concave washer, a thin washer, and a steel hex nut. The wedge-shaped washer was used to set the pad "toe-in.”

V-Brakes by Shimano or Avid had a cable bridge at the top of the right arm that held the noodle and a left arm with a cable clamp. The arms of my P-Brakes were identical. The cable bridge and macaroni-sized cable guide I designed was a welded unit. You had to bend the tip of a brake cable to push it through the macaroni. Since no cable clamp was incorporated into any arm, I used an adjustable cable barrel clamp. This design allowed me to place the macaroni on either side, which gave me more freedom in routing my brake cables. A Teflon liner inside the macaroni reduced friction.

I made a set of hubs later on. As a cyclist with an engineering background, ideas for bike components have popped up over the years. But early into my career, I moved away from manufacturing. Making stuff isn’t impossible without personal connections to people in manufacturing or being in a company with manufacturing capabilities. A machine shop will make anything you want if you hand them a big pile of cash. But, whenever I asked myself if it was worth spending a small fortune to bring a silly idea to life or build a bike with components already on the market, I chose the latter. My disposable income has always allowed me to own very nice bikes, but made-to-my-spec parts were out of reach.

entry.title: Mavic Cycling Shoes
entry.summary: I usually stay loyal to a brand when something works or fits well. When you look at my bike fleet, you’ll easily spot a bunch of those brands. There’s Rotor for cranks, SRAM for shifting, Hope for braking, and Prologo for sitting. You’ll see René Herse, WTB, and Zipp on multiple bikes. I have the same brand loyalty for everything I wear on the bike. I move on to other brands from time to time, but it always happens gradually. I used to wear Giro helmets exclusively in the past. While I still have two old ones, I’ve moved to Lazer for road and gravel and Smith for snow and dirt. On the opposite end of my body, my feet slip into the shoes of two brands. There’s Mavic for warm and dry days and Northwave for cold or wet days.

I switched to Mavic shoes in 2011 with a pair of metallic silver Tempo shoes. A bunch of different road and MTB shoes by Mavic followed. The most expensive of them all, Mavic’s Crossmax SL Pro Ultimate, is a shoe pair I rode for a whopping 8 years. While it’s still a usable pair of shoes, I decided to replace them. Only when you place an old pair of shoes next to a new pair do you realize how much they’ve aged.

There’s a lot of complaining that cycling has become an expensive sport. I don’t agree with that. Cycling is only as expensive as you want it to be. The Cosmic and Crossmax are the cheapest cycling shoes from the seven pairs I’ve bought since 2011. Both of them are extremely similar, yet there are some subtle differences. The Crossmax Boa is marketed as an MTB shoe, whereas the Cosmic Boa’s target audience is gravel riders. They share the same upper shoe construction. The Crossmax Boa has a heavier, more aggressive rubber outsole. The Cosmic Boa has a lighter outsole, supposedly with exceptional abrasion resistance for those walks on asphalt when you stop for coffee. I’ll probably use the Crossmax Boa for gravel rides and wear the Cosmic Boa when I stay on the road.

entry.title: Updating Brakes Round Two
entry.summary: Back in mid-July, I updated the Hope brakes on my Volagi Viaje. I replaced the original RX4 calipers with the new and improved RX4+. Whereas the old RX4 used 2x14 mm and 2x11 mm pistons, Hope increased the pistons to 2x16 mm and 2x14 mm for the RX4+ calipers. I paid little attention to the pads then, but once out of the box, I immediately realized that RX4 and RX4+ calipers shared different brake pads. The original pads for SRAM RX4 calipers are 30.8mm wide. The width of the pads increased to 37.0mm for RX4+ calipers. That's a 20% size increase.
entry.content:
Back in mid-July, I updated the Hope brakes on my Volagi Viaje. I replaced the original RX4 calipers with the new and improved RX4+. Whereas the old RX4 used 2x14 mm and 2x11 mm pistons, Hope increased the pistons to 2x16 mm and 2x14 mm for the RX4+ calipers. I paid little attention to the pads then, but once out of the box, I immediately realized that RX4 and RX4+ calipers shared different brake pads. The original pads for SRAM RX4 calipers are 30.8mm wide. The width of the pads increased to 37.0mm for RX4+ calipers. That's a 20% size increase.

When brake pads push against a rotor, they produce friction, and the kinetic energy is converted into heat. Larger pads, just like pistons, and rotors dissipate heat better. They require less braking pressure to produce the same braking force. Less pressure translates to less pad wear. The RX4+ calipers with the massive pistons also look amazingly cool. It was therefore time to treat the Nordest Albarda to a new set of calipers. The Nordest has gone through so many updates over the years that only five things remain from the original build; the frame, the fork, the headset, the saddle, and the cranks.

The RX4 flat-mount calipers I took of my Albarda are 5 years old. They still work and look like on day one. When I built the Marin Gestalt X12, budget-minded me used SRAM Rival calipers. They looked great in their all-black finish. The calipers have two quite large pistons but in comparison with Hope calipers, they have fairly small pads. Brake performance is good but not mind-blowing. Brake pad life is decent. They need adapter plates front and back. The calipers are made of two halves bolted together with two steel bolts. While elegantly shaped, this makes them a bit bulky.

I retreated into the basement and replaced the SRAM calipers with the Hope RX4 calipers from my Albarda. All I had to do was cut the SRAM olives and barbs off the hoses and add the ones from Hope. In the heat of the battle, I forgot to check hose lengths. I could have shortened the front hose by another 5 to 10 mm. The Marin lost some weight (full disclaimer - I didn't weigh the two caliper pairs), gained some braking power, and looks cooler, too.

entry.title: DJI Neo - The Perfect Cyclist's Drone
entry.summary: I got my feet wet using a drone for cycling photography in the spring of 2017 when I bought a Yuneec Breeze 4K. It showed me two things at the time. Firstly, I was able to capture some amazing photos. Secondly, drone technology wasn't ready.
entry.content:
I got my feet wet using a drone for cycling photography in the spring of 2017 when I bought a Yuneec Breeze 4K. It showed me two things at the time. Firstly, I was able to capture some amazing photos. Secondly, drone technology wasn't ready. I continued to follow the development of consumer drones. With DJI's release of the Neo, the first drone that I consider "ready" has arrived. If you're into flying drones and have the time and money for it, very capable drones have been available for years. But if you wanted something that does the job, and does the job quickly and easily, there was nothing remotely comparable to the Neo until now.

What makes it such a great drone for cycling? For one, its weight and small form factor. At 135 grams and a size of 130×157×48.5 mm, it doesn't take much room in a backpack, and you barely carry any extra weight. Next is control. The easiest way to use the Neo is through Palm Control. After powering it on, you use the mode button to switch among multiple intelligent shooting modes. Follow and spotlight will be the modes you use most often for cycling.

Mobile App Control is the better choice for more control and peace of mind while riding. Mount your smartphone to the handlebar, and you can keep an eye on the drone or change flight modes while the Neo remains in flight. The best thing for cyclists is Voice Control through the Fly App. While you’re riding, you can use voice commands such as “follow,” “brake,” “higher,” “lower,” “farther,” and many more. You can keep both hands firmly on your bars, and your eyes can stay focused on the road. I use voice commands all the time.

My fall 2024 photo album already has close to 100 photos I’ve taken with the Neo. I’ve only pulled out my iPhone 12 or DJI Action 2 camera fourteen times to snap a photo during the summer.
